awd_titl_txt: Noyce Scholars: Preparing STEM Teachers to Serve in High-Need, Rural School Districts
awd_abstract_narration:
The Noyce Track 1 project at Dordt College will employ innovative methods to recruit, prepare, and retain 31 highly-qualified STEM teachers to teach in high-need rural school districts. STEM teachers are a key aspect in the preparation of K-12 students for careers in STEM fields. The national shortage of STEM teachers is no less of an issue in rural schools than in other parts of the nation, with 23% - 36% unfilled STEM education positions in rural schools. Teachers in small, rural districts are often the only STEM education experts in the district and serve as teachers leading not only in their classrooms, but also STEM education district-wide. A single Dordt College scholar may teach 180 students a year for as many as 40 years, impacting over 7,000 students in a career. The potential number of students in rural communities educated by these highly qualified STEM teachers over a five-year period could impact thousands of students.

Dordt College and Northwest Iowa Community College, along with Le Mars and West Sioux Community School Districts, plan to partner together to address the acute shortage of STEM teachers through this Noyce Scholars project which will encourage and support highly-talented STEM majors to become teachers in high-need, rurally-located local educational agencies. To accomplish these goals, the project will take a two-pronged approach: (a) The project will provide scholarship and cohort experiences targeted to 31 academically strong STEM students to recruit, develop, and support expanded numbers of STEM education candidates prepared to teach in rural settings. Cohort experiences will include 1) shared courses, 2) peer mentoring, 3) growth mindset training, and 4) networking and support during and after degree completion. (b) The project will expand recruiting for students at the K-12 and collegiate levels and enhance the college's professional learning network. Outreach efforts to support this approach will include 1) activities such as camps, visit days and STEM competitions for K-12 students providing enrichment and vocational discernment opportunities, 2) collegiate student outreach for both Dordt College students and local community college students, and 3) teacher networking opportunities including workshops, teacher circles, and professional learning communities.  This project will provide valuable insight into best practices for recruiting and preparing highly qualified STEM teachers. The innovative use of personal learning networks and growth mindset training will provide important insights into the metacognitive and social aspects of potential and early-career STEM teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The Noyce Scholars: Preparing STEM Teachers to Serve in High-Need, Rural School Districts at Dordt University began June 1, 2017 and ended in May 31, 2023. The goals set out for this project and their outcomes were to:

Goal 1: Expand recruiting of students at K-12 schools

Recruitment of students at K-12 schools expanded over this project to include a high school Math Challenge, a March Madness Data Analytics Battle for 6th - 12th grade students, Math Bees for 4th, 5th, 7th, and 8th grade students, STEAMfest for 4th - 8th grade students, Ag Bio-Tech tours for high school students, and an Ag Day for Kindergarten through college age students..

Goal 2: Enhance professional learning communities with an increased number of practicing STEM teachers in rural areas participating in numerous outreach and professional learning activities and opportunities.

The Math Teacher Circle started in 2014 and grew over the project to an average of 18 attendees each month. The Principal Investigator's Twitter account is dedicated to promoting and supporting STEM education and the DC Noyce Scholars program. The number of Twitter impressions increased each of the first five years to over 25,000 impressions per year for the #dunoyce hashtag. Changes to the Twitter platform and the resulting changes in use of Twitter by the broader population significantly decreased this impact in the final year.

Goal 3: Support at least 31 additional highly-talented teacher candidates (54 scholarship awards funded over 5-year grant)

The project was successful in supporting highly-talented teacher candidates; 30 undergraduate students were awarded 52.5 scholarships. It should be noted that a no-cost extension was necessary to award the scholarships. Twenty-three of the Noyce scholars have already graduated with a majority serving in high-needs rural schools. The Noyce program created momentum at Dordt University with a total of 28 students majoring in STEM education by the final year of the grant.

A unique aspect of the program included growth mindset training for all Noyce Scholars. External evaluations revealed that scholars theories of intelligence regarding a growth mindset towards teaching STEM was consistently positive and showed increases on pre-test posttest evaluations for each year.

The Noyce Scholars program also developed six new pathways into STEM teaching.

  • Late Entry: A 4-semester pathway for STEM majors who pursue education later in college
  • 5th Year Option: A 12-month post-baccalaureate option for STEM graduates
  • Two-Year Students: A pathway from 2-year degree programs at DU and community colleges into STEM education
  • Joint Math Physics: Results in a math and physics teaching endorsement
  • Engineering: Results in engineering teaching endorsement
  • Joint Math Engineering: Results in math and engineering teaching endorsements.

Project leadership disseminated the results of the project on topics including the promotion of STEM education, fostering growth mindset (for pre- and in-service teachers), teacher preparation, K-12 partnerships, and an array of activities to attract majors (mini-internships, pathways into STEM education), engaging K-12 students in mathematics (data analytics battle, mathematical gaming), and fostering a professional learning network. This was conducted through in-person and virtual presentations at conventions, conferences, summits, professional development sessions, and outreach activities (community, collegiate, and K-12). The audiences were local, regional, national, and international.

In summary, the project was successful in meeting its goal and the project staff eagerly anticipate the continuation of this work in future Noyce grants.


Last Modified: 08/21/2023
Modified by: Valorie L Zonnefeld
